node.title: What is the new definiton of a close contact agreed upon by national cabinet?
node.description: National cabinet has agreed on what defines aÂ person as a close contact of a COVID-19 case. So, how does that differ from what rules were in place for each state and territory previously?
node.content:
["National cabinet has agreed on what defines a\u00a0person as a close contact of a COVID-19 case.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0", "Until now,\u00a0that definition was different in each state and territory.", "Now\u00a0Prime Minister Scott Morrison says a close contact will\u00a0be someone who has spent four hours or more with a confirmed case in a household or household-like setting, such as a residential care facility.", "Those contacts would only be required to quarantine for seven days, and take a rapid antigen test (RAT) on day six.", "He says\u00a0the new definition would\u00a0come into effect from Friday\u00a0in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia\u00a0and the ACT.", "Tasmania will follow on January 1, while the Northern Territory will make announcements about its plans in the coming days.", "West Australian\u00a0Premier Mark McGowan said the state agrees with the changes but\u00a0that was only relevant for states with thousands of daily cases.", "This means Western Australia\u00a0will continue with its existing close contact and isolation rules for the time being.", "Yesterday, Mr\u00a0Morrison said:\u00a0\"It is important that we move to a new definition of close contact that enables Australia to keep moving, for people to get on with their lives.\"", "
So how does that differ from what rules were (or are)\u00a0in place in each state and territory?
", "Let's take a look.", "In some jurisdictions, a specific\u00a0amount of time a person needed\u00a0to spend with a COVID-positive case was not given to define them as being a close contact.\u00a0", "For example,\u00a0NSW had defined\u00a0a close contact as:\u00a0\"Someone who has been close enough to a person with COVID-19 (a 'case') while they were infectious, that they have a reasonable chance of also getting COVID-19.\"", "It's a similar message from\u00a0the Northern Territory, which states: \"A\u00a0close contact is someone who has been near enough to a person with COVID-19 while they were infectious that there is a possibility they will have been infected with COVID-19.\"", "South Australia did\u00a0not state\u00a0how long a \"lengthy social interaction\" with a COVID-positive case was exactly, instead it said:\u00a0\"A close contact is a person who has had face-to-face contact with someone who is COVID-19 positive, where there is reasonable risk of transmission. This will include: the household contacts of the person with COVID-19,\u00a0people the person with COVID-19 had lengthy social interaction with.\"", "In Western Australia, the government says\u00a0a close contact is: \"A\u00a0person who has had face-to-face contact OR shared a close space, for any amount or\u00a0duration, with someone who has been diagnosed with COVID-19 (while they were considered infectious).\"", "However, in the ACT, authorities were\u00a0a bit more explicit about what defined\u00a0someone as\u00a0a close contact. The ACT government website stated: \"A\u00a0close contact is anyone who has spent significant time with you since the two\u00a0days prior to either the start of your COVID-19 symptoms or your test date, whichever is earlier.", "\"This is known as your infectious period. ACT Health will tell you this date during the phone call or survey.", "\"Close contacts include: All your household members,\u00a0someone who has spent more than 4 hours with you (this might be 4 hours in a row or 4 hours made up of shorter times) in the same room or small area in a\u00a0house,\u00a0building,\u00a0accommodation,\u00a0care facility.\"", "", "
The rules for COVID\u00a0close contacts won't change for people in Western Australia.(Pexels: cottonbro)
", "For Tasmania, the amount of time spent with a COVID-positive case is much less to determine as a close contact.\u00a0The Tasmanian government website advised: \"A\u00a0close contact is generally someone who has had at least 15 minutes face-to-face contact with a case.", "\"A person might still be a close contact if they have spent less than 15 minutes face-to-face with a case but there is some risk of transmission based on: one or both people are not vaccinated;\u00a0PPE has not been used appropriately;\u00a0the setting increases the risk, e.g., is indoors, small room, poor ventilation;\u00a0the specific variant of COVID-19;\u00a0the nature of the exposure increases the risk, e.g., shouting or singing.\"", "Queensland echoed\u00a0the same calls, describing\u00a0a close contact as:\u00a0\"A\u00a0person who has had at least 15 minutes face-to-face contact or shared an enclosed space with a COVID-19 case, and there is a reasonable risk of infection.", "\"This will include household contacts, extensive social interaction with a case or being present at a high-risk setting.\"", "In Victoria, close contacts were classified under different settings.\u00a0", "These have been:\u00a0household contacts, social contacts, workplace contacts, education contacts and other contacts.\u00a0\u00a0", "In the household setting, you can be determined as a close contact\u00a0if: \"You live with someone who has COVID-19 or have spent more than four hours with them at a private residence, accommodation or care facility.\"", "", "
How accurate are rapid antigen tests?
"]
